body_html:
@psyhtest I've been using Debian unstable (which is supposed to be Debian 10 under development at this time) to build TensorFlow master branch on my board and chroot() Android devices more than one year, which includes 1.4 to 1.9, without running into offsetof() problem.

So, if your environment has offsetoff() problem, I think probably the "right" solution is to add something like,

#ifdef MY_DEBIAN_WHATEVER_WITHOUT_OFFSETOF
#define offsetof(type, member) ......
#endif

@psyhtest I've been using Debian unstable (which is supposed to be Debian 10 under development at this time) to build TensorFlow master branch on my board and chroot() Android devices more than one year, which includes 1.4 to 1.9, without running into offsetof() problem.
So, if your environment has offsetoff() problem, I think probably the "right" solution is to add something like,
#ifdef MY_DEBIAN_WHATEVER_WITHOUT_OFFSETOF
#define offsetof(type, member) ......
#endif
body:
@psyhtest I've been using Debian unstable (which is supposed to be Debian 10 under development at this time) to build TensorFlow master branch on my board and chroot() Android devices more than one year, which includes 1.4 to 1.9, without running into `offsetof()` problem. 

So, if your environment has `offsetoff()` problem, I think probably the "right" solution is to add something like, 
```
#ifdef MY_DEBIAN_WHATEVER_WITHOUT_OFFSETOF
#define offsetof(type, member) ......
#endif
````
